question: You are a code expert. Please use your professional knowledge to generate accurate and professional responses. Ensure that the code you generate is executable for demonstration. Create a lottery system for opening vocabulary boxes in the Peace Elite (PUBG Mobile) subway escape mode, with the requirement that it can replace weapons and vocabulary content.

checklist.title: Is the lottery system core mechanism fully implemented?
checklist.description: Review whether the code accurately implements the lottery probability algorithm, including weighted random selection, guarantee mechanism (pity system), and rarity distribution. Check if different vocabulary box types have distinct drop rates and if the probability calculation follows standard gacha mechanics. Score 0 if core lottery logic is missing, 5 if only basic random selection is implemented, and 10 if complete probability system with guarantee mechanism is included.

checklist.title: Is the vocabulary and weapon replacement system properly designed?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the system allows dynamic content replacement for both weapons and vocabulary items. Check if the data structure supports easy modification of item pools, rarity levels, and metadata. Verify that the replacement mechanism maintains consistency in item properties and visual representations. Deduct 5 points if hardcoded item lists are used, and 3 points if item metadata is incomplete. Full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the opening animation and visual feedback system complete?
checklist.description: Check whether the lottery opening sequence includes proper visual effects such as box opening animations, rarity reveal effects, and item showcase presentations. Evaluate if the animation timing creates appropriate suspense and excitement. Verify that different rarity items have distinct visual treatments. Deduct 5 points if animations are missing or too basic, and 3 points if rarity differentiation is unclear. Full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the inventory and collection management system implemented?
checklist.description: Assess whether the system includes comprehensive inventory management with item storage, collection tracking, and usage statistics. Check if duplicate handling is properly managed and if players can view their collection history. Verify that item organization follows logical categorization. Deduct 5 points if inventory persistence is not implemented, and 3 points if duplicate item handling is missing. Give 10 points if fully implemented with statistics.

checklist.title: Is the code robust?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the code can handle common abnormal situations (such as invalid probability configurations, missing item data, concurrent lottery requests, etc.) and provide friendly error prompts or recovery mechanisms. Code with strong robustness should be able to effectively handle these edge cases, giving 10 points. If the robustness is average, give 5 points, and if no exceptions are handled, give 0 points.

checklist.title: Are there any innovative features that are eye-catching?
checklist.description: Check whether the code includes surprise features that enhance the experience (e.g., 1. Multi-box opening with batch results 2. Item preview with 3D models 3. Achievement system for rare item collection 4. Social sharing of rare drops). Add 3 points for each practical innovative feature implemented (maximum 10 points).

checklist.title: Are there any redundant features?
checklist.description: Strictly check three types of redundancy: 1. Redundant implementation of similar functions (e.g., multiple random generators coexisting) 2. Function modules unrelated to lottery system (e.g., built-in chat system) 3. Excessive visual effects that impact performance (e.g., complex particle systems for every item). Deduct 3 points for each redundancy found, and directly deduct 10 points if core lottery functions are interfered with by redundant code.

checklist.title: Does the code have engineering quality?
checklist.description: Review modular design (such as separating lottery logic/UI/data layers), configuration management, and code maintainability. Deduct 5 points if global state pollution is found or design patterns are not used; deduct 5 points if the code duplication rate is too high (over 30%); deduct 5 points if item configuration is not externalized. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Does the interface vision meet professional design standards?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the overall design follows modern game UI principles: 1) Gaming-appropriate color scheme with proper rarity color coding (Common/Rare/Epic/Legendary) 2) Proper layout spacing with clear visual hierarchy 3) Professional typography with readable font sizes (≥14px for body text). Deduct 3 points for each crowded visual element, 5 points for poor rarity color distinction, and 5 points for chaotic item layout. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the dynamic interaction smooth and seamless?
checklist.description: Judge whether the lottery interactions conform to gaming standards: 1) Box opening trigger response ≤100ms 2) Opening animation duration 2-4 seconds for proper suspense 3) Clear visual feedback for item rarity reveals 4) Smooth transitions between lottery states. Deduct 5 points for each interaction without proper feedback, 3 points for jarring animation transitions, and 5 points for unclear rarity reveal sequences. The full score is 10 points.
